achieved.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
2

• (j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee's
performance annually thereafter.
5 of 17 employee files reviewed did not meet the requirements for the written
evaluation for each file. This involved 3 evaluations being beyond the 180 days
and 2 not being completed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility was offered technical assistance in the area of developing a tracking
system to ensure all required tasks are completed timely.
• The facility was offered technical assistance in the area of developing a system to
have all policies placed in a general location and available to staff.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility was offered consultation in the area of developing an electronic record
keeping system to ensure all information is available and located in the same
area.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility has submitted two corrective action plans during this reporting period.
The first CAP was in response to the violations found during the renewal licensing
inspection which took place on 3/11/24. The violations included Rule 400.4155 (1)
in which three initial residential service plans were completed late, Rule 400.4166
in which one closed youth file did not have a discharge summary documented in
the file, Rule 400.4166 (1)(c) one closed youth file did not have an assessment of
the youth’s needs that remain to be met, Rule 400.4166 (1)(b) one closed youth
3

file did not have a brief summary of the services provided documented in the file,
and Rule 400.4166 (1)(d) one closed youth file did not have documentation of
what services would be provided by the facility after discharge. The approved CAP
involves the Supervisor/Quality Assurance staff to monitor monthly for due dates
and completed reports. The Supervisor and Case manager will verify completion
of discharge summaries within 3 days and continue to monitor for discharge
summaries monthly. The Supervisor and Case Manager will also monitor monthly
discharge summaries. All the above-mentioned actions involve the Supervisor
sending out calendar reminders to staff about the need to complete the task.
During this investigation none of these issues were discovered to be in non-
compliance. The second correction action plan was in response to the special
investigation 2025SIC0000030 with an approved CAP. The violation involved the
use of seclusion of a youth (Rule 400.4162). This CAP involves the retraining of all
staff on policy of behavior support and management, retraining on Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPI) and documentation indicated the training was provided
on 10/1/24, 10/30/24, 1/14/25, 1/15/25, and 1/17/25. The third action step was
rescheduled due to a lack of funding, but the facility is still planning on completing
the Collaborative Problem-Solving training.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator identified there are 6 youth in care at this time and 7
discharges have taken place in the past year. He also identified being the new
Chief Administrator. The facility continues with their contract with Global Refuge to
accommodate refugee and immigrant foster minors who are unaccompanied under
the care of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. He reported no restraints during
this past year. The Chief Administrator identified the absence of a comprehensive
and consistent onboarding process which has led to a lack in personnel’s ability to
gain knowledge thus hindering their ability to provide adequate oversight and set
clear expectations and priorities. He reported that the facility has outlined and
implemented several interventions, action steps and ongoing maintenance efforts
to foster a culture of accountability. He also reported finding full compliance with the
timeliness and professional quality of reports including the discharge summaries
and service plans. This is a result of the changes put into place for the CAP
required by the renewal licensing inspection. The Chief Administrator reported one
unplanned discharge since the last inspection. The facility has worked to identify
potential warning signs and created a plan to enhance services, supervision, and
4

communication with the youth. Regarding the second CAP for the special
investigation, he reports progress on two of the three action steps. He also reported
that the facility’s efforts to remain in compliance involve regular communication on
all issues and a focus on developing effective strategies to meet desired program
outcomes when needed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed shared a report of a high investment in the youth doing well and
appeared to use the best practices approach when dealing with the youth. Staff
also reported receiving significant training to help deal with different issues the
youth might present. Administration is also invested in the youth doing well and
report a strong effort to meet the different needs of the youth.
All four of the youth in the program currently were interviewed. They reported
feeling safe at the facility and believed the program is beneficial to meet their
needs. All report receiving therapy session both individually and in a group setting.
They also reported a belief that the staff are invested in their wellbeing and are
attentive to their needs.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a single-story facility in excellent condition and very well maintained in all
aspects. The structure is only a few years old and provides an excellent space for
the youth. There is a fully stocked kitchen and a different space for the youth to
cook specific foods in an effort to enhance their independent living skills. All
plumbing is in working order and cleaning supplies are locked away from the youth.
The medications are behind 2 locked doors and locked in cabinets in the
medication room. Items requiring posting were found posted appropriately. Fire
extinguishers were up to date and fire drills logs were also appropriate. Room
check logs are documented as being completed appropriately.
5

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
